content: A robot uprising was mentioned on another thread, so I thought I'd post this and open it up for discussion. quote: Robot attacked Swedish factory worker Published: 28 Apr 09 10:12 CET Online: *http://www.thelocal.se/19120/20090428/* A Swedish company has been fined 25,000 kronor ($3,000) after a malfunctioning robot attacked and almost killed one of its workers at a factory north of Stockholm. Public prosecutor Leif Johansson mulled pressing charges against the firm but eventually opted to settle for a fine. "I've never heard of a robot attacking somebody like this," he told news agency TT. The incident took place in June 2007 at a factory in Bålsta, north of Stockholm, when the industrial worker was trying to carry out maintenance on a defective machine generally used to lift heavy rocks. Thinking he had cut off the power supply, the man approached the robot with no sense of trepidation. But the robot suddenly came to life and grabbed a tight hold of the victim's head. The man succeeded in defending himself but not before suffering serious injuries. "The man was very lucky. He broke four ribs and came close to losing his life," said Leif Johansson. The matter was subject to an investigation by both the Swedish Work Environment Authority (Arbetsmiljöverket) and the police. Prosecutor Johansson chastised the company for its inadequate safety procedures but he also placed part of the blame on the injured worker. Will all robots obey the Three Laws? Or will they split into factions - robots who abide by the Three Laws and more independent minded robots who consider the Asimovist robots fools?
quote: Robot attacked Swedish factory worker Published: 28 Apr 09 10:12 CET Online: *http://www.thelocal.se/19120/20090428/* A Swedish company has been fined 25,000 kronor ($3,000) after a malfunctioning robot attacked and almost killed one of its workers at a factory north of Stockholm. Public prosecutor Leif Johansson mulled pressing charges against the firm but eventually opted to settle for a fine. "I've never heard of a robot attacking somebody like this," he told news agency TT. The incident took place in June 2007 at a factory in Bålsta, north of Stockholm, when the industrial worker was trying to carry out maintenance on a defective machine generally used to lift heavy rocks. Thinking he had cut off the power supply, the man approached the robot with no sense of trepidation. But the robot suddenly came to life and grabbed a tight hold of the victim's head. The man succeeded in defending himself but not before suffering serious injuries. "The man was very lucky. He broke four ribs and came close to losing his life," said Leif Johansson. The matter was subject to an investigation by both the Swedish Work Environment Authority (Arbetsmiljöverket) and the police. Prosecutor Johansson chastised the company for its inadequate safety procedures but he also placed part of the blame on the injured worker.

content: Jeeze... all the guy did was trip one of the robot's sensors and its program took over. We are not to the point of Asmov's three laws yet. Wonder if it was a Fanuc? BTW: I have worked on lines that it was impossible to render "lock out, Tag out" inert as well. And we ran 480v as well. Deenergizing the sub-assembly to work on was sometimes an all day job... LOL. Those were the good old days
